title: Contributing to cageminer
text: outlines propose change cageminer. detailed info contributing , tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide.

title: Contributing to cageminer
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to cageminer
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to cageminer
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("almeidasilvaf/cageminer", fork = TRUE). Install development dependences devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to cageminer
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to cageminer
text: Please note cageminer project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting help with cageminer
text: Thanks using cageminer! filing issue, places explore pieces put together make process smooth possible.

title: Getting help with cageminer
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty insane ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Getting help with cageminer
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. See also Bioconductor help website. ’s question: start community.rstudio.com, /StackOverflow. Bioconductor-related question, please ask Bioconductor Support Website using appropriate package tag (website send automatic email package authors). people answer questions. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

title: Getting help with cageminer
text: efficient possible, development tidyverse packages tends bursty, shouldn’t worry don’t get immediate response. Typically don’t look repo sufficient quantity issues accumulates, ’s burst intense activity focus efforts. makes development efficient avoids expensive context switching problems, cost taking longer get back . process makes good reprex particularly important might multiple months initial report start working . can’t reproduce bug, can’t fix !

title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: past years, RNA-seq data several species accumulated public repositories. Additionally, genome-wide association studies (GWAS) identified SNPs associated phenotypes interest, agronomic traits plants, production traits livestock, complex human diseases. However, although GWAS can identify SNPs, identify causative genes associated studied phenotype. goal cageminer integrate GWAS-derived SNPs transcriptomic data mine candidate genes identify high-confidence genes associated traits interest.

title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: use cageminer research, please cite us. can obtain citation information citation('cageminer'), demonstrated :
code: print(citation('cageminer'), bibtex = TRUE) #>  #> To cite cageminer in publications use: #>  #>   Almeida-Silva, F., & Venancio, T. M. (2022). cageminer: an #>   R/Bioconductor package to prioritize candidate genes by integrating #>   genome-wide association studies and gene coexpression networks. in #>   silico Plants, 4(2), diac018. #>   https://doi.org/10.1093/insilicoplants/diac018 #>  #> A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is #>  #>   @Article{, #>     title = {cageminer: an R/Bioconductor package to prioritize candidate genes by integrating genome-wide association studies and gene coexpression networks}, #>     author = {Fabricio Almeida-Silva and Thiago M. Venancio}, #>     journal = {in silico Plants}, #>     year = {2022}, #>     volume = {4}, #>     number = {2}, #>     pages = {diac018}, #>     url = {https://doi.org/10.1093/insilicoplants/diac018}, #>     doi = {10.1093/insilicoplants/diac018}, #>   }

title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
code: if(!requireNamespace('BiocManager', quietly = TRUE))   install.packages('BiocManager') BiocManager::install("cageminer") # Load package after installation library(cageminer) set.seed(123) # for reproducibility

title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: vignette, use transcriptomic data pepper (Capsicum annuum) response Phytophthora root rot (Kim et al. 2018), GWAS SNPs associated resistance Phytophthora root rot Siddique et al. (2019). ensure interoperability Bioconductor packages, expression data stored SummarizedExperiment objects, gene/SNP positions stored GRanges objects.
code: # GRanges of SNP positions data(snp_pos) snp_pos #> GRanges object with 116 ranges and 0 metadata columns: #>       seqnames    ranges strand #>          <Rle> <IRanges>  <Rle> #>     2    Chr02 149068682      * #>     3    Chr03   5274098      * #>     4    Chr05  27703815      * #>     5    Chr05  27761792      * #>     6    Chr05  27807397      * #>   ...      ...       ...    ... #>   114    Chr12 230514706      * #>   115    Chr12 230579178      * #>   116    Chr12 230812962      * #>   117    Chr12 230887290      * #>   118    Chr12 231022812      * #>   ------- #>   seqinfo: 8 sequences from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths  # GRanges of chromosome lengths data(chr_length)  chr_length #> GRanges object with 12 ranges and 0 metadata columns: #>        seqnames      ranges strand #>           <Rle>   <IRanges>  <Rle> #>    [1]    Chr01 1-272704604      * #>    [2]    Chr02 1-171128871      * #>    [3]    Chr03 1-257900543      * #>    [4]    Chr04 1-222584275      * #>    [5]    Chr05 1-233468049      * #>    ...      ...         ...    ... #>    [8]    Chr08 1-145103255      * #>    [9]    Chr09 1-252779264      * #>   [10]    Chr10 1-233593809      * #>   [11]    Chr11 1-259726002      * #>   [12]    Chr12 1-235688241      * #>   ------- #>   seqinfo: 12 sequences from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths  # GRanges of gene coordinates data(gene_ranges)  gene_ranges #> GRanges object with 30242 ranges and 6 metadata columns: #>           seqnames              ranges strand |   source     type     score #>              <Rle>           <IRanges>  <Rle> | <factor> <factor> <numeric> #>       [1]    Chr01         63209-63880      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>       [2]    Chr01       112298-112938      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>       [3]    Chr01       117979-118392      + |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>       [4]    Chr01       119464-119712      + |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>       [5]    Chr01       119892-120101      + |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>       ...      ...                 ...    ... .      ...      ...       ... #>   [30238]    Chr12 235631138-235631467      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>   [30239]    Chr12 235642644-235645110      + |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>   [30240]    Chr12 235645483-235651927      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>   [30241]    Chr12 235652709-235655955      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>   [30242]    Chr12 235663655-235665276      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>               phase          ID          Parent #>           <integer> <character> <CharacterList> #>       [1]      <NA>  CA01g00010                 #>       [2]      <NA>  CA01g00020                 #>       [3]      <NA>  CA01g00030                 #>       [4]      <NA>  CA01g00040                 #>       [5]      <NA>  CA01g00050                 #>       ...       ...         ...             ... #>   [30238]      <NA>  CA12g22890                 #>   [30239]      <NA>  CA12g22900                 #>   [30240]      <NA>  CA12g22910                 #>   [30241]      <NA>  CA12g22920                 #>   [30242]      <NA>  CA12g22930                 #>   ------- #>   seqinfo: 12 sequences from an unspecified genome; CA03g35110 CA02g12750 #> rowData names(0): #> colnames(45): PL1 PL2 ... TMV-P0-3D TMV-P0-Up #> colData names(1): Condition

title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: mining high-confidence candidates, can visualize SNP distribution genome explore possible patterns. First, let’s see SNPs uniformly across chromosomes plot_snp_distribution().  can see, SNPs associated resistance Phytophthora root rot tend co-occur chromosome 5. Now, can see close genome, located gene-rich regions. can visualize plot_snp_circos, displays circos plot SNPs across chromosomes.  seems clustering gene-rich regions, can see SNPs chromosome tend physically close . SNP positions multiple traits, need store GRangesList CompressedGRangesList objects, element SNP positions particular trait. , can visualize distribution single trait. Let’s simulate multiple traits see works:
code: plot_snp_distribution(snp_pos) plot_snp_circos(chr_length, gene_ranges, snp_pos) # Simulate multiple traits by sampling 20 SNPs 4 times snp_list <- GenomicRanges::GRangesList(   Trait1 = sample(snp_pos, 20),   Trait2 = sample(snp_pos, 20),   Trait3 = sample(snp_pos, 20),   Trait4 = sample(snp_pos, 20) )  # Visualize SNP distribution across chromosomes plot_snp_distribution(snp_list) # Visualize SNP positions in the genome as a circos plot plot_snp_circos(chr_length, gene_ranges, snp_list)

title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: cageminer algorithm identifies high-confidence candidate genes 3 steps, can interpreted 3 sources evidence: Select genes sliding window relative SNP putative candidates. Find candidates step 1 coexpression modules enriched guide genes (genes known associated trait interest). Find candidates step 2 correlated condition interest. 3 steps can executed individually (users want control happens step) .

title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: run candidate mining step step, need functions mine_step1(), mine_step2, mine_step3.

what: Step 1: finding genes close to (or in linkage disequilibrium with) SNPs
title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: function mine_step1() identifies genes based step 1 returns GRanges object putative candidates location genome. , need give 2 GRanges objects input, one gene coordinates1 another SNP positions. first step identified 1265 putative candidate genes. default, cageminer uses sliding window 2 Mb select putative candidates2. want visually inspect simulation different sliding windows choose different one, can use simulate_windows().
code: candidates1 <- mine_step1(gene_ranges, snp_pos) candidates1 #> GRanges object with 1265 ranges and 6 metadata columns: #>          seqnames              ranges strand |   source     type     score #>             <Rle>           <IRanges>  <Rle> | <factor> <factor> <numeric> #>      [1]    Chr02 147076830-147083477      + |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>      [2]    Chr02 147084450-147086637      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>      [3]    Chr02 147099482-147104002      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>      [4]    Chr02 147126373-147126537      + |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>      [5]    Chr02 147129897-147132335      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>      ...      ...                 ...    ... .      ...      ...       ... #>   [1261]    Chr12 232989761-232990947      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>   [1262]    Chr12 232994658-232999784      + |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>   [1263]    Chr12 233001307-233004705      + |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>   [1264]    Chr12 233005539-233011740      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>   [1265]    Chr12 233018159-233022142      - |  PGA1.55     gene        NA #>              phase          ID          Parent #>          <integer> <character> <CharacterList> #>      [1]      <NA>  CA02g16550                 #>      [2]      <NA>  CA02g16560                 #>      [3]      <NA>  CA02g16570                 #>      [4]      <NA>  CA02g16580                 #>      [5]      <NA>  CA02g16590                 #>      ...       ...         ...             ... #>   [1261]      <NA>  CA12g21190                 #>   [1262]      <NA>  CA12g21200                 #>   [1263]      <NA>  CA12g21210                 #>   [1264]      <NA>  CA12g21220                 #>   [1265]      <NA>  CA12g21230                 #>   ------- #>   seqinfo: 12 sequences from an unspecified genome; no seqlengths length(candidates1) #> [1] 1265 # Single trait simulate_windows(gene_ranges, snp_pos) # Multiple traits simulate_windows(gene_ranges, snp_list)

what: Step 2: finding coexpression modules enriched in guide genes
title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: function mine_step2() selects candidates coexpression modules enriched guide genes. , users must infer GCN function exp2gcn() package BioNERO (Almeida-Silva Venancio 2021). Guide genes can either character vector guide gene IDs data frame gene IDs first column annotation second column (useful guides divided functional categories, instance). , pepper genes associated defense-related MapMan bins retrieved PLAZA 3.0 Dicots (Proost et al. 2015) used guides. resulting object list two elements: candidates: character vector mined candidate gene IDs. enrichment: data frame enrichment results. step 2, got 37 candidates.

what: Step 3: finding genes with altered expression in a condition of interest
title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: function mine_step3() identifies candidate genes whose expression levels significantly increase decrease particular condition. , need specify level sample metadata corresponds condition. resulting object mine_step3() data frame mined candidates correlation condition interest. Finally, got 5 high-confidence candidate genes associated resistance Phytophthora root rot. Genes negative correlation coefficients condition can interpreted significantly reduced expression condition, genes positive correlation coefficients significantly increased expression condition.
code: # See the levels from the sample metadata unique(pepper_se$Condition) #> [1] "Placenta"      "Pericarp"      "PRR_control"   "PRR_stress"    #> [5] "virus_control" "PepMov_stress" "TMV"  # Apply step 3 using "PRR_stress" as the condition of interest candidates3 <- mine_step3(pepper_se, candidates = candidates2$candidates,                           sample_group = "PRR_stress") candidates3 #>           gene      trait        cor       pvalue #> 243 CA12g18400 PRR_stress  0.5963394 1.540534e-05 #> 187 CA10g02780 PRR_stress  0.3201048 3.205995e-02 #> 19  CA02g16620 PRR_stress  0.3113993 3.732128e-02 #> 33  CA02g16900 PRR_stress -0.3204388 3.187100e-02 #> 103 CA03g03310 PRR_stress -0.3983772 6.720204e-03

title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: Alternatively, interested inspecting results step, can get results previous section single step using function mine_candidates(). function wrapper calls mine_step1(), sends results mine_step2(), sends results mine_step2() mine_step3().
code: candidates <- mine_candidates(gene_ranges = gene_ranges,                                marker_ranges = snp_pos,                                exp = pepper_se,                               gcn = gcn, guides = guides$Gene,                               sample_group = "PRR_stress") #> Enrichment analysis for module brown... #> Enrichment analysis for module cyan... #> Enrichment analysis for module darkgreen... #> Enrichment analysis for module darkmagenta... #> Enrichment analysis for module darkolivegreen... #> Enrichment analysis for module darkorange... #> Enrichment analysis for module darkorange2... #> Enrichment analysis for module darkred... #> Enrichment analysis for module darkturquoise... #> Enrichment analysis for module green... #> Enrichment analysis for module grey60... #> Enrichment analysis for module ivory... #> Enrichment analysis for module lightcyan... #> Enrichment analysis for module midnightblue... #> Enrichment analysis for module orange... #> Enrichment analysis for module orangered4... #> Enrichment analysis for module paleturquoise... #> Enrichment analysis for module pink... #> Enrichment analysis for module red... #> Enrichment analysis for module royalblue... #> Enrichment analysis for module salmon... #> Enrichment analysis for module steelblue... #> Enrichment analysis for module violet... candidates #>           gene      trait        cor       pvalue #> 243 CA12g18400 PRR_stress  0.5963394 1.540534e-05 #> 187 CA10g02780 PRR_stress  0.3201048 3.205995e-02 #> 19  CA02g16620 PRR_stress  0.3113993 3.732128e-02 #> 33  CA02g16900 PRR_stress -0.3204388 3.187100e-02 #> 103 CA03g03310 PRR_stress -0.3983772 6.720204e-03

title: Mining high-confidence candidate genes with cageminer
text: cases, might high-confidence candidates expected, want pick top n genes validation, instance. scenario, need assign scores mined candidates pick top n genes highest scores. function score_genes() using formula : \[S_i = r_{pb} \kappa\] : \(\kappa\) = 2 gene encodes transcription factor \(\kappa\) = 2 gene hub \(\kappa\) = 3 gene encodes hub transcription factor \(\kappa\) = 1 none conditions true default, score_genes picks top 10 candidates. less 10 candidates, return candidates sorted scores. , TFs obtained PlantTFDB 4.0 (Jin et al. 2017). Hub genes can identified function get_hubs_gcn() package BioNERO. none mined candidates hubs encode transcription factors, scores simply correlation coefficients condition interest.
code: # Load TFs data(tfs) head(tfs) #>      Gene_ID Family #> 1 CA12g20650    RAV #> 2 CA00g00130   WRKY #> 3 CA00g00230   WRKY #> 4 CA00g00390    LBD #> 5 CA00g03050    NAC #> 6 CA00g07140 E2F/DP  # Get GCN hubs hubs <- BioNERO::get_hubs_gcn(pepper_se, gcn) head(hubs) #>         Gene Module  kWithin #> 1 CA02g16370  brown 36.54361 #> 2 CA11g18340  brown 36.49363 #> 3 CA06g01660  brown 36.35147 #> 4 CA02g18750  brown 34.79498 #> 5 CA11g18360  brown 34.01593 #> 6 CA12g07260  brown 33.73551  # Score candidates scored <- score_genes(candidates, hubs$Gene, tfs$Gene_ID) #> Number of genes < 'pick_top'. Picking all genes. scored #>           gene      trait        cor       pvalue      score #> 243 CA12g18400 PRR_stress  0.5963394 1.540534e-05  0.5963394 #> 103 CA03g03310 PRR_stress -0.3983772 6.720204e-03 -0.3983772 #> 33  CA02g16900 PRR_stress -0.3204388 3.187100e-02 -0.3204388 #> 187 CA10g02780 PRR_stress  0.3201048 3.205995e-02  0.3201048 #> 19  CA02g16620 PRR_stress  0.3113993 3.732128e-02  0.3113993

code: @Article{,   title = {cageminer: an R/Bioconductor package to prioritize candidate genes by integrating genome-wide association studies and gene coexpression networks},   author = {Fabricio Almeida-Silva and Thiago M. Venancio},   journal = {in silico Plants},   year = {2022},   volume = {4},   number = {2},   pages = {diac018},   url = {https://doi.org/10.1093/insilicoplants/diac018},   doi = {10.1093/insilicoplants/diac018}, }

title: Candidate Gene Miner
text: goal cageminer integrate SNP data GWAS results gene coexpression networks identify high-confidence candidate genes involved particular phenotype. identify high-confidence candidate genes, cageminer considers 3 criteria: Physical proximity (linkage disequilibrium ) trait-related SNPs; Presence coexpression modules enriched guide genes (.e., “reference” genes known associated phenotype). Significant altered expression levels condition interest (e.g., stress, disease, etc). default, cageminer defines genes high-confidence candidates satisfy 3 criteria , users can choose use one/.

text: Mine high-confidence candidate genes single step

title: Mine high-confidence candidate genes in a single step — mine_candidates
code: mine_candidates(   gene_ranges = NULL,   marker_ranges = NULL,   window = 2,   expand_intervals = TRUE,   gene_col = "ID",   exp = NULL,   gcn = NULL,   guides = NULL,   metadata,   sample_group,   min_cor = 0.2,   alpha = 0.05,   continuous = FALSE )

title: Mine high-confidence candidate genes in a single step — mine_candidates
text: gene_ranges GRanges object genomic coordinates genes genome. marker_ranges Genomic positions SNPs. single trait, GRanges object. multiple traits, GRangesList CompressedGRangesList object, element list representing SNP positions particular trait. window Sliding window (Mb) upstream downstream relative SNP. Default: 2. expand_intervals Logical indicating whether expand markers represented intervals. particularly useful users want use custom interval defined linkage disequilibrium, example. Default: TRUE. gene_col Column GRanges object containing gene ID. Default: "ID", default gff/gff3 files imported rtracklayer::import. exp Expression data frame genes row names samples column names SummarizedExperiment object. gcn Gene coexpression network returned BioNERO::exp2gcn(). guides Guide genes character vector data frame genes first column gene annotation class second column. metadata Sample metadata samples row names sample information first column. Ignored exp SummarizedExperiment object, colData extracted object. sample_group Level sample metadata used filtering gene-trait correlation. min_cor Minimum correlation value BioNERO::gene_significance(). Default: 0.2 alpha Numeric indicating significance level. Default: 0.05 continuous Logical indicating whether metadata continuous . Default: FALSE

title: Mine high-confidence candidate genes in a single step — mine_candidates
text: data frame mined candidate genes correlation condition interest.

title: Mine high-confidence candidate genes in a single step — mine_candidates
code: # \donttest{ data(pepper_se) data(snp_pos) data(gene_ranges) data(guides) data(gcn) set.seed(1) candidates <- mine_candidates(gene_ranges, snp_pos, exp = pepper_se,                               gcn = gcn, guides = guides$Gene,                               sample_group = "PRR_stress") #> Enrichment analysis for module cyan... # }

what: Step 1: Get all putative candidate genes for a given sliding window — mine_step1
title: Step 1: Get all putative candidate genes for a given sliding window — mine_step1
text: user-defined sliding window relative SNP, function subset genes whose genomic positions overlap sliding window.

title: Step 1: Get all putative candidate genes for a given sliding window — mine_step1
Step 1: Get all putative candidate genes for a given sliding window — mine_step1
text: gene_ranges GRanges object genomic coordinates genes genome. marker_ranges Genomic positions SNPs. single trait, GRanges object. multiple traits, GRangesList CompressedGRangesList object, element list representing SNP positions particular trait. window Sliding window (Mb) upstream downstream relative SNP. Default: 2. expand_intervals Logical indicating whether expand markers represented intervals. particularly useful users want use custom interval defined linkage disequilibrium, example. Default: TRUE.

title: Step 1: Get all putative candidate genes for a given sliding window — mine_step1
text: GRanges GRangesList object genomic positions putative candidate genes.

title: Step 1: Get all putative candidate genes for a given sliding window — mine_step1
code: data(snp_pos) data(gene_ranges) genes <- mine_step1(gene_ranges, snp_pos, window = 2)

what: Step 2: Get candidates in modules enriched in guide genes — mine_step2
title: Step 2: Get candidates in modules enriched in guide genes — mine_step2
text: Step 2: Get candidates modules enriched guide genes

title: Step 2: Get candidates in modules enriched in guide genes — mine_step2
Step 2: Get candidates in modules enriched in guide genes — mine_step2
text: exp Expression data frame genes row names samples column names SummarizedExperiment object. gcn Gene coexpression network returned BioNERO::exp2gcn(). guides Guide genes character vector data frame genes first column gene annotation class second column. candidates Character vector candidates genes inspected.

title: Step 2: Get candidates in modules enriched in guide genes — mine_step2
text: list 2 elements: candidates Character vector candidates step 2 enrichment Data frame results enrichment analysis

title: Step 2: Get candidates in modules enriched in guide genes — mine_step2
code: data(pepper_se) data(guides) data(gcn) set.seed(1) mine2 <- mine_step2(pepper_se, gcn = gcn, guides = guides$Gene,                     candidates = rownames(pepper_se)) #> Enrichment analysis for module cyan...

what: Step 3: Select candidates based on gene significance — mine_step3
title: Step 3: Select candidates based on gene significance — mine_step3
text: Step 3: Select candidates based gene significance

title: Step 3: Select candidates based on gene significance — mine_step3
code: mine_step3(   exp,   metadata,   candidates,   sample_group,   min_cor = 0.2,   alpha = 0.05,   continuous = FALSE )

title: Step 3: Select candidates based on gene significance — mine_step3
text: exp Expression data frame genes row names samples column names SummarizedExperiment object. metadata Sample metadata samples row names sample information first column. Ignored exp SummarizedExperiment object, colData extracted object. candidates Character vector candidate genes inspected. sample_group Level sample metadata used filtering gene-trait correlation. min_cor Minimum correlation value BioNERO::gene_significance(). Default: 0.2 alpha Numeric indicating significance level. Default: 0.05 continuous Logical indicating whether metadata continuous . Default: FALSE

title: Step 3: Select candidates based on gene significance — mine_step3
text: data frame mined candidate genes correlation condition interest.

title: Step 3: Select candidates based on gene significance — mine_step3
code: data(pepper_se) data(snp_pos) data(gene_ranges) data(guides) data(gcn) data(mine2) set.seed(1) mine3 <- mine_step3(pepper_se, candidates = mine2$candidates,                     sample_group = "PRR_stress")

what: Score candidate genes and select the top n genes — score_genes
title: Score candidate genes and select the top n genes — score_genes
text: Score candidate genes select top n genes

title: Score candidate genes and select the top n genes — score_genes
code: score_genes(   mined_candidates,   hubs = NULL,   tfs = NULL,   pick_top = 10,   weight_tf = 2,   weight_hub = 2,   weight_both = 3 )

title: Score candidate genes and select the top n genes — score_genes
text: mined_candidates Data frame resulting mine_candidates() mine_step(). hubs Character vector hub genes. tfs Character vector transcription factors. pick_top Number top genes select. Default: 10. weight_tf Numeric scalar weight correlation coefficients multiplied gene TF. Default: 2. weight_hub Numeric scalar weight correlation coefficients multiplied gene hub. Default: 2. weight_both Numeric scalar weight correlation coefficients multiplied gene TF hub. Default: 3.

title: Score candidate genes and select the top n genes — score_genes
text: Data frame top n candidates scores.

title: Score candidate genes and select the top n genes — score_genes
code: data(tfs) data(hubs) data(mined_candidates) set.seed(1) scored <- score_genes(mined_candidates, hubs$Gene, tfs$Gene_ID) #> Number of genes < 'pick_top'. Picking all genes.

text: gene_ranges GRanges object genomic coordinates genes genome. marker_ranges Genomic positions SNPs. single trait, GRanges object. multiple traits, GRangesList CompressedGRangesList object, element list representing SNP positions particular trait. windows Sliding windows (Mb) upstream downstream relative SNP. Default: seq(0.1, 2, = 0.1). expand_intervals Logical indicating whether expand markers represented intervals. particularly useful users want use custom interval defined linkage disequilibrium, example. Default: TRUE.
